title: Why do some people have an incredible memory while others don't? How can we improve our memory? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a very complicated question to answer. It’s both nature and nurture. There’s genetics that plays a role in the brain function. A gene called APOE4 has been associated with Alzheimer’s and memory in general. It regulates the receptors in the hippocampus, a region known for turning short-term memory to long-term ones. But it’s more than just your genetics. Epigenetics is a thing for a reason. When we remember a piece of information, we reconstruct sensory information and experience it the way we stored it. There are also different types of memories. When a piece of information fires down constantly in certain pathways and through the hippocampus, neurotransmitters are binding to the α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptor, known as AMPAR and the N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor also known as the NMDAR. The latter helps in long term potentiation, which is responsible for your brain’s ability to learn. The more the neurons fire, the more the receptors are triggered and eventually certain proteins and enzymes make additional AMPAR and NMDAR receptors along the neuron’s membrane making it more sensitive to future signals, thus easier to remember. This part is the nurture part. This part is what you can improve. As you can see, the mechanism is quite easy; use the information. There’s no secret or magic to it. You can use many techniques to remember, associate things with one another. Another thing that plays a role is the emotional impact of information. When an event is emotional the amygdala is activated - so is the hippocampus - and this dual activation makes the memory stronger. The activation of both makes the synapses stronger and therefore the connections as well
